awd_titl_txt: NSF-MRI: Acquisition of a Microwave Radiometer for Arctic Atmospheric Boundary Layer Research & Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This Major Research Instrumentation award is for the acquisition of a Microwave Radiometer to enhance high-latitude Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL) research and applied areas of Air Pollution Meteorology, Mesoscale Modeling and Low Level Cloud-ABL interaction. This instrument will enhance the research capabilities at the University of Alaska Fairbanks into important topics for Air Pollution and Human Health, connected to the ABL dynamics and Air Quality. The instrument will also be used as an educational tool for use by a diverse cohort of undergraduate and graduate students including Alaskan Natives and underrepresented minority groups coming to Alaska seeking for an Arctic-focused research and education opportunity. 

The research team will acquire the RPG-HATPRO-G5 from RPG Radiometer Physics, which is the latest generation of microwave radiometers with enhanced capability for low humidity atmospheres. The team will incorporate the Microwave Radiometer into the existing Arctic Facility for Atmospheric Remote Sensing at the Department of Atmospheric Sciences, University of Alaska Fairbanks and will be combined with Lidar and surface-based turbulence instrumentation. The instrument will also be prepared to be deployed into a mobile unit for field studies. Topics of study that will be enhanced by this instrument acquisition includes: a) improve understanding of surface fluxes and ABL dynamic states; b) provide high resolution description of the ABL structure during the buildup and breakup of surface based temperature inversions; c) improve understanding of dynamic-radiative interaction between elevated synoptic temperature inversions layers and the surface based inversions; d) provide experimental observations of the winter ABL structure to support the International Global Atmospheric Chemistry - Alaskan Layered Pollution and Chemical Analysis (IGAC-ALPACA); e) support Fire Weather applications detailing the summer ABL structure and f) improve mesoscale modeling for renewable energy applications and, g) support educational programs including dynamic meteorology with Arctic focus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF-MRI: Acquisition of a Microwave Radiometer (MWR) for Atmospheric Boundary Layer Research and Education.

PI: Dr. Javier Fochesatto (gjfochesatto@alaska.edu).

Department of Atmospheric Sciences. University of Alaska Fairbanks.

Under this funding the purchase of the Microwave Radiometer was executed. The selected instrument was the RPG-HATPROG5 series from Radiometer Physics (https://www.radiometer-physics.de/), Germany.  

The instrument presents significant electronic and technological advances in microwave radiation sensing and signal processing for atmospheric products determination in comparison with the current available technology.

The instrument works on direct detection where each channel comes after the microwave filtering coupled to an ultralow noise conditioner amplifier which significantly improves the performance compared to microwave radiometers based on heterodyne detection existing in the market. The MWR was also engineered for operations in cold weather conditions and a fan was added coupled to a heater and a proper housing so that the instrument keeps the front-end optics (i.e., scanning mirror) free of moisture and frost. This is important to reduce self-induced errors in water vapor detection specially in cold climates. The instrument has two microwave sensing bands tuned in the oxygen and water vapor microwave emissions bands. In this way the instrument is able to deduce, based on a trained neural network signal processing software, the temperature and water vapor profiles with one-minute time resolution.

Project Milestones:

Instrument was set in the Field during IGAC-ALPACA Experiment Winter 2022.

The insturment outputs was compared to radiosounding systems.

It has also been calibrated in the field and in the lab.

Outcomes have been presented in the AMS 103 2023 and AMS 104 2024 as well as in the AGU meeting 2023. 

Major outcomes from this MRI project are:

1.     The MWR is participating of the ALPACA PBL (2022-2025) follow-on project funded by NSF PDM. This field experiment will be conducted during the winters 2023-2024 and 2024-2025.

2.     The MWR is included in the new curriculum design of graduate courses for Advance Instrumentation in Meteorology developed to infuse high-end technology in the newly developed Earth System Sciences – Atmospheric and Climate Sciences track.

Budget Expenditures: 

Co-PI Dr. Nicole Moelders retired inmediately the funding was awarded. So then PI Fochesatto develpeed the software needed to adapt the MWR outputs to fast reading of atmospheric models (e.g., WRF). This software was already used to build up the MWR-datasets for model intercomparisson. Once Feb 2024 is finishesd the two year datasets will be merged into the NSF-Arctic Data Center.-
